requiredMaterials.title: Thermodynamics: An Engineering Approach
requiredMaterials.format: Digital through Inclusive Access ($48.75 auto-added to tuition)
requiredMaterials.properties: Steam, Refrigerant-134a, air, and select ideal gas properties in appendices

coursePurpose: Advance along the path from BYU student to engineer in the world: solves problems, gives your best, embraces the Holy Ghost, lives authentic discipleship, and finds joy and balance in career, family, social, and gospel living

learningOutcomes.description: Use structured techniques to develop engineering problem statements based on real-world applications and solve engineering problems
Write technical theory section, results and discussion section, and create figures consistent with specified guidelines

learningOutcomes.outcome: Thermodynamic Systems, States, Properties and Processes
learningOutcomes.description: Characterize material comprising systems, use state postulate to fix state, obtain properties using appropriate methods, describe processes and sketch on diagrams
Use conservation of mass and energy to model open and closed systems undergoing transient and steady processes
Identify irreversibilities, determine reversibility classifications, use entropy balance equations to model systems
Describe operation of engineering devices and models used to represent them
List devices and describe processes in power and refrigeration cycles; build models to analyze and evaluate cycles
Recognize role of thermodynamics in addressing economic and environmental concerns; make informed judgements consistent with ethical and professional responsibilities

courseExpectations: Attend lectures, ask questions, give answers; actively engage during mini reviews and practice problems
Course is difficult - requires consistent and diligent effort
Reading assignments take approximately 30 minutes each
Homework problems take significant time - avoid procrastination
Material is challenging but can be fun; thermodynamics affects our lives in incredible ways
Put forth honest best effort; instructor provides every opportunity to thrive
Personal integrity expected; group study encouraged but copying without intellectual engagement is cheating

types.purpose: Help you learn material but not assess knowledge

types.purpose: Assess ability to apply concepts to new problems

homework.submission: Scanned copies uploaded digitally by midnight on due date
homework.selfGradesSubmission: Submit graded score under Homework Report in Learning Suite within 48 hours of due date
homework.scalingFormula: (100 × sum of scores) / (10N) where N = number of problems

latePolicy.general: Late homework not accepted in general
latePolicy.exception: One exception allowed - email to Brian Easthope with no penalty
latePolicy.lateReportScores: If emailed within 24 hours: 5-point penalty; after 24 hours: 15-point penalty

components: Based on thermodynamics problem of your choosing

honorCode.standard: Students expected to be honest in all academic work

honorCode.dressAndGrooming: Expected to adhere to BYU standards

aiPolicy.overview: You will need to use generative AI (ChatGPT, etc.) in your engineering career; learn now so not disadvantaged at graduation
aiPolicy.principle1Preparation: May use AI to prepare for class, study for exams, and brainstorm for assignments; not to replace course materials or reading quizzes
aiPolicy.principle2Homework: May use AI sparingly to get unstuck but sparingly discouraged; growth comes from overcoming challenges; work should reflect intellectual engagement
aiPolicy.principle3Exams: Generative AI may not be used in any exam situation
